Issues.Title: fix(ivy): process creation mode deeply before running update mode
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, we had two different modes for change detection
execution for Ivy, depending on whether you called `bootstrap()` or
`renderComponent()`. In the former case, we would complete creation
mode for all components in the tree before beginning update mode for
any component. In the latter case, we would run creation mode and
update mode together for each component individually.

Maintaining code to support these two different execution orders was
unnecessarily complex, so this commit aligns the two bootstrapping
mechanisms to execute in the same order. Now creation mode always
runs for all components before update mode begins.

This change also simplifies our rendering logic so that we use
`LView` flags as the source of truth for rendering mode instead of
`rf` function arguments. This fixed some related bugs (e.g. calling
`ViewRef.detectChanges` synchronously after the view's creation
would create view nodes twice, view queries would execute twice, etc).

Issues.Title: ES2015 iteration not supported
Issues.Body:
Iterating over an ES2015 collection is not supported in our compilation. Ex:

```javascript
const edges = new Set([1, 2, 3]);
for (const edge of edges) { ... }
```

It gets transpiled correctly when built under Bazel, but will fail on Travis in the old `build.sh` system, as that uses a set of `tsconfig`s and a version of TS that don't seem to support it. The error is:

```
error TS2569: Type 'Set<T>' is not an array type or a string type. Use compiler option '--downlevelIteration' to allow iterating of iterators.
```

Issues.Title: Clarity and/or discussion on "private" property/method naming
Issues.Body:
# 📚 Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description I was hoping to gain more clarity or talk about a "nice to have" in regards to the [Angular Styleguide suggestion](https://angular.io/guide/styleguide#properties-and-methods) not to use the underscore prefix for "private" properties and methods if possible. Specifically, it's use and the way "private" interacts from ts within templates between the default dev and prod builds - it seems like there could be a gap here. [This question ](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27615) helps illustrate part of the issue, and has been talked about at length in a few more references (and more), [here_1](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/26393), [here_2](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/16893). While these talk more specifically about access methods conflicting with prop names, I wanted to bring up the interaction with templates. Issues [like this one](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27615), while they are not a problem with the framework, throwing an error that a property is "private" while looking at the template currently requires extra step(s) ([explained more here](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/11978#issuecomment-255736505)). While JavaScript (default ng serve / ES5) does not care about "private," tsc (default prod build) does.TS has support for letting the developer know if a private property or method is being used, but I'm not familiar with a way of seeing this in the templates. Developers who are more familiar with Angular may not have an issue here, but using a pattern like this could be a "nice to have" for newer/unfamiliar developers, or a timesaving naming/visual pattern when working in templates. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/guide/styleguide#properties-and-methods ### Reproduction Steps** ``` ng new test-ng cd test-ng ``` Inside of app.component.ts: ``` public test = 'test'; private testPrivate = 'testPrivate'; private _testPrivate = '_testPrivate'; ``` and inside of app.component.html: ```
{{test}}
{{testPrivate}}
{{_testPrivate}}
``` Running the default `ng serve` works just fine as expected / noted above, but `ng build --prod` will fail (also as expected). The difference (at least for me) is that with the IDEs I've used, I can immediately tell by looking just at the template that `_testPrivate` probably is private- ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** Actual behavior: while it's an agreed upon mistake by the developer, no ahead of time warning for private props/methods in templates, requires additional steps. Expected: Can be a range from noting the alternative naming with underscore, adding more detail to the existing info of TS vs JS "private", or leave the docs alone and provide/suggest tooling out of the box that catches this at dev time.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clarity and/or discussion on "private" property/method naming" (#27760)

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package `@angular/animation` (any version)

### Description
1. There is an array of numbers
2. There is a parent container that generates multiple child items with a ngFor loop using that array.
3. Each item gets its number from the array assigned.

When the array contains identical numbers and you remove one of the duplicate numbers you run into a problem. Issues.Body:
<!--

### Versions
<!--

  Windows (7/8/10). Linux (incl. distribution). macOS (El Capitan? Sierra? High Sierra?)
-->
node - 8.12.0
npm - 6.4.1
ng - 7.0.4
macOS - Sierra

### Repro steps
<!--
Simple steps to reproduce this bug.
Please include: commands run (incl args), packages added, related code changes.
A link to a sample repo would help too.
-->
n/a

### The log given by the failure
<!-- Normally this include a stack trace and some more information. -->
n/a

### Story

At my job, we have built our own library of shared angular components. We have budget sizes configured in the `angular.json`. As with any active project, the bundle size tends to increase over time. That can cause our automated pull request tests to fail on even a small code change if the change adds enough size to go over the max/min threshold (5% in this example).

"budgets": [{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "main",
								"baseline": "4020kb",
								"minimumError": "5%",
								"maximumError": "5%"
							},{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "styles",
								"baseline": "181kb",
								"minimumError": "5%",
								"maximumError": "5%"
							}]


When this happens, the error is easy to identify and remedy (thanks for that!). However, this puts us in a tricky situation. 
> ng build --prod
  
> Date: 2018-12-19T20:13:36.383Z
> Hash: 9ee44adbae1ca37d967f
> Time: 59917ms
> chunk {0} runtime.ec2944dd8b20ec099bf3.js (runtime) 1.41 kB [entry] [rendered]
> chunk {1} main.2e3d8a71c52f17d81367.js (main) 1.39 MB [initial] [rendered]
> chunk {2} polyfills.f31412eb35fb595ae0a2.js (polyfills) 147 kB [initial] [rendered]
> chunk {3} styles.c38cc6ec26a52983595d.css (styles) 170 kB [initial] [rendered]
> 
> ERROR in budgets, maximum exceeded for main. Budget 1.4 MB was exceeded by 1.39 kB.

- If we pick a min/max threshold that is **larger**, it increases the chance of introducing a bad import or dependency that dramatically increases the bundle size. 
- If we pick a min/max threshold that is **smaller**, it increases the occurrence of small code changes that push us past our budget.

Budget sizes are known to be a difficult configuration to determine. @jenniferfell has an open item for this topic https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/26106

### Desired functionality
<!--
What would like to see implemented?
What is the usecase?
-->

An optional configuration to auto increment your budget sizes would allow developers to set a comfortable max/min amount that their bundle is allowed to change in size. This could be baked into the `build` command or a new command that would ideally be used before `build`. This would allow your budgets to update organically with your project size but large changes (like adding or removing a third party dependency) would require a manual adjustment to the budget baseline.

#### Example use:

An organization has an `angular.json` file with a configuration that allows for auto updating when the difference in bundle size is less than 5%.

"budgets": [{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "main",
								"baseline": "4020kb",
								"minimumAutoIncrement": "5%",
								"maximumAutoIncrement": "5%",
                                                                   "autoIncrement": "true"
							},{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "styles",
								"baseline": "181kb",
								"minimumError": "5%",
								"maximumError": "5%",
                                                                   "autoIncrement": "false" // this would default to false to not break existing usage
							}]

User A works and commits their final change. Before pushing a branch up, they run the optional build command (or a new command) `ng build --update-budget` and then commit the updated `angular.json`. When User B reviews the PR, they would notice that the budget baseline value was adjusted to equal the old budget +/- the delta amount of the code change. Budget sizes that exceed the min/max auto increment configuration would still throw an error and maintain their role as a warning to large bundle size changes.

### Mention any other details that might be useful
<!-- Please include a link to the repo if this is related to an OSS project. -->

Incorporating this into version control/continuous integrated environments could be tricky as the Angular-CLI would be modifying versioned files and not the user. 

An individual solution that uses the [Bundle-Budget plugin](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/plugins/bundle-budget.ts) to increment the bundle size could be built and added to a company's existing processes.

Figured it was an interesting enough issue to discuss here. Thank you.

After typescript 3.2 upgrade, I've started seeing e2e test failures due to certain symbols not being defined - in all cases these symbols came from rxjs and were aliased to a different name.

The problem occurs during dev builds without optimizations turned on and causes both `ng serve` and `ng e2e` to fail with runtime errors in the browser

```
import { from as fromPromise, Observable } from 'rxjs';
``` 
Would end up with `fromPromise` being undefined at runtime.

- remove the `as` alias and refactor the code to use the original symbol name.
- revert back to typescript 3.1

I'll try to create a minimal reproduction outside of aio but for now you can review the "workaround" commit in https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/27536/commits

In the meantime I've tested the `as` imports in vanilla tsc and it seems to be working just fine there, so I suspect that it's some kind of interaction with cli or webpack that is causing this.

Issues.Title: Branch manager should check diff instead of patch
Issues.Body:
Consider you have multiple commits within a PR, first commits adds a file, second commit renames the file.

The patch for that change will not apply with `git apply` because the patches are not run sequentially and therefore `git apply` will throw when it tries renaming the file in the second commit.

e.g. 

```patch
From 5fa1e23cb00a04c9b084f8634c7e7cea9b413d8e Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Paul Gschwendtner <paulgschwendtner@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, 19 Dec 2018 20:54:09 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] My second PR commit

---
 srcs/my-file.txt => my-new-name-file.txt | 0
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 rename srcs/my-file.txt => my-new-name-file.txt (100%)

diff --git a/srcs/my-file.txt b/my-new-name-file.txt
similarity index 100%
rename from srcs/my-file.txt
rename to my-new-name-file.txt
-- 
2.19.1.windows.1

From aaa9e380164af93d92982aca740bb56696ae2879 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Paul Gschwendtner <paulgschwendtner@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, 19 Dec 2018 20:53:54 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] First PR commit

---
 srcs/my-file.txt | 0
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 srcs/my-file.txt

diff --git a/srcs/my-file.txt b/srcs/my-file.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..e69de29
-- 
2.19.1.windows.1
```

We should rather just check the PR's `.diff` file that just reflects the difference and nothing more. This also makes sure that subsequent commits in a PR can become green if previous commits didn't apply properly. As an example: see #14565

Issues.Title: Number type inputs should use getLocaleNumberFormat to enforce input of correct number.
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Depending on the locale that is set, inputs of type `number` should automatically adapt the number format of the locale, so that every client has consistent results when entering i.e. a dot or comma into the app. So for English locale only dot should be allowed as decimal, for German only comma.

#### What is the current behavior?
You can use both , and . as separators. The output of the number is largely depending on the browser. See this as reference: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15303940/how-to-handle-floats-and-decimal-separators-with-html5-input-type-number

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material2-issue-ckhlp5?file=app%2Fapp.component.html
Both 1,2 and 1.2 are recognized as valid number input, resulting in the following values being parsed into the `value`variable:

| input | value in ff | value in chrome |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1.2 | 1.2 | 1.2 |
| 1,2 | none | 1.2 |

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Definitely Angular 6 and 7.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Number type inputs should use getLocaleNumberFormat to enforce input of correct number." (#14575)

Issues.Title: CDK Overlay: ViewportMargin per side
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

It would be nice to be able to define the viewport margin for each side independently (similar to a css margin).

Something like

```ts
interface ViewportMargin {
    top: number,
    right: number,
    bottom: number,
    left: number
}

viewPortMargin: number | ViewportMargin;
```

would be nice to have.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

I'd like to make sure my overlay is only shown within the "main" area of my application and not on top of the action bar or sidenav. (Injecting a custom OverlayContainer and a second Overlay service instance limited to my desired area doesn't work since it still uses the ViewportRuler for calculation).

#### Is there anything else we should know?
